text: hi there my name is Nils and in this
video I'm going to be showing you how to
make an outdoor freestanding projector
screen that is large affordable
collapsible and totally portable also be
sure to stick around for the end of the
video where I'll show you this tiny
little projector that packs a real punch
and is the perfect companion to this
projector screen the projector screen
we're going to be building is made of
PVC and will hold steady in windy areas
like where we live it provides a great
picture and is perfect for outdoor movie
nights with family and friends for this
project I used a good quality screen
material that I purchased from Amazon
this is Carl's blackout cloth which you
can pick up for about $35 links are in
the description while you can use a
bedsheet or other material this cloth is
designed for projector screens there's a
finish side and a back you can hear the
difference lie the screen on your carpet
scratchy side up which is the back and
fold over each side about 3 to 4 inches
or 8 to 10 centimetres to make the
pockets for the PVC pipe you can either
use stitch witchery which is an adhesive
strip for fabric or just sew it I tried
both and the stitch witchery stuff while
a great option if you don't have access
to a sewing machine it's kind of a pain
it requires you to lay it down between
the fabric put a towel under it so as
not to melt your carpet put a damp cloth
over it and then iron each side for
about 10 seconds each all the way along
the length of it I tried this for one
side and it took a while so I headed
over to the sewing machine and sew the
other three sides both held up equally
well but the sewing machine was much
faster you don't need to be an expert
tailor or seamstress this is what I call
functional sewing it just needs to get
the job done when you're done with each
side cut a square in each of the four
corners so that you can push the PVC
pipes through them when you're done you
should have a screen that is
approximately 16 by 9 ratio and it
should look roughly like this next I did
a bit of man sweeping in the garage to
keep my screen from getting too dirty
when I laid it out and started getting
my measurements be sure to take multiple
measurements in case your sides aren't
perfectly straight for my screens the
measurements were 102 inches wide by 50
eight inches high I'm using one and a
half inch PVC for this build
take your width measurement and start by
subtracting two inches to accommodate
for the one inch depth of the elbows for
the top and bottom rails I'm going to
break it down into two sections so that
the kit is a little bit more portable
you'll lose about a quarter inch because
of the coupling so you'll need to
subtract that as well
lastly divide that result by two so that
you can break your pipe into two
sections you'll need four pieces two for
the top and two for the bottom the sides
are much simpler just subtract two
inches from the height and you're all
set you should end up with four
identically sized pieces for the top and
bottom rails and two slightly longer
identical size pieces for the sides
you've got several options for cutting
the PVC the first is to use a PVC pipe
cutter these are pretty inexpensive and
links are in the description they're
super easy to use
they're also the cleanest option if you
have a hacksaw you can use that too but
it is a lot of work and a lot of mess
plus you're going to have to sand every
cut because it leaves them pretty rough
if you have access to a miter saw or
chop saw that's definitely the easiest
and quickest way to go that's what I
chose to use for this project once
you've got your six pieces cut lay them
out for a quick test fit to make sure
everything lines up and then try to fit
them into the screen and see how that
goes if it's too big that's okay we want
to start a little large we want to cut
the pipes down until they barely fit and
that's what's going to keep the tension
on the screen and stretch it tight to
get rid of the wrinkles and the creases
keep adjusting until you get it to fit
nice and tighten
once that's squared away you can make
the cuts for the legs and feet the stand
is just two feet and a leg for each side
I made my feet about 18 inches wide so
that the base would be about three feet
across and the legs were about two feet
high but feel free to adjust as needed
put these together with one T and two
end caps each then attach them to the
screen to stand it up tada
the screen is almost done now if you
want to add some tie downs for windy
conditions one way to do that is to
drill a hole into each side of the
vertical poles about halfway up drill
through the outside of the PVC and then
slightly into the other side but not
through the reason for that is you can
drive a three inch screw into each side
and it will
right into place these act as the
connector for the tie-downs
drives mistakes into the ground or you
can just use some heavy objects like
your kids and then use paracord to tie
the screen to the stakes or the kids be
sure to have a helper if you're setting
the screen up in very windy conditions
like you see here you can then use a
lighter to melt the ends of the paracord
to prevent fraying with that you're all
done except that you're not I thought I
was finished but then I noticed the
horizontal folds I came up with a
solution for this that works pretty well
I created a stretcher bar to fit between
the top and bottom poles I had to make a
small cut in the sleeves at the top and
bottom and then I put a three inch screw
at the top and the bottom of a pole and
spaced them just far enough apart that
they stretched the top and bottom poles
apart with the stretcher bar in place
the wrinkles were almost gone and the
only one that was left was really small
and didn't even show up when the screen
was in use now it's done and backyard
movie night is on oh and check out that
tiny little projector in the corner now
as we wrap up there's one little part I
definitely want to show you guys I think
it's something really awesome that I
wanted to share because it's kind of
what inspired me to do this project this
little projector that you see standing
on the tripod mount here want to build a
cheap tripod mount with your existing
tripod click the link at the top of the
screen and I'll show you how is hardly
bigger than a cell phone and it's
actually running this whole projector
screen here and it's got about a
bazillion little features that make it
totally awesome for one thing this thing
is 100% Wireless and I'm not saying like
it has Wi-Fi and that's it but it has
Wi-Fi it has Bluetooth and it's
battery-powered so you can literally
take this thing out into the mountains
to a campsite set up your portable
screen like this take this thing with
you you don't need any wires you don't
need to generate or anything like that
you don't even need the Wi-Fi you can
actually load movies onto a microSD card
and pop them in there
you can also airplay from your iOS
device or you can cast from an Android
device and watch that way I mean it is
pretty impressive so be sure to check it
out you can hook it up to a Bluetooth
speaker so that you have wireless sound
you can even put the sound behind the
screen so it's coming right from the
screen and you've got yourself a pretty
amazing completely wireless outdoor
setup two more things about it that I
think you know
just kind of blew my mind there isn't
actually a touchpad right on top here so
I'm actually able to move the mouse
around and navigate through this Android
based device and I can use Netflix I can
use YouTube anything like that so if
you're streaming this in the backyard
you've got everything you need right
there
these little guys run about two hundred
and forty dollars on Amazon and if you
use the links in the description below
those are affiliate links so it kind of
helps me out it doesn't cost you any
extra and it supports my channel so I
hope you enjoyed the video if you have
